query: What is the absolute difference in tens of thousands between the population of chinstrap penguins on the Wikipedia page for penguin species populations as of the end of 2018 and the population recorded in the Nature.com "global population assessment of the Chinstrap penguin" article from 2020, assuming two penguins per breeding pair?

used_evidence: The population of chinstrap penguins was estimated to be around 8 million in 2018.
The assessment reports approximately 3.42 million breeding pairs of Chinstrap penguins.

tasks.description: Find the Wikipedia page for penguin species populations as of the end of 2018.

result.query: Find the Wikipedia page for penguin species populations as of the end of 2018.

facts.fact: The population of chinstrap penguins was estimated to be around 8 million in 2018.
The population of emperor penguins was estimated at 513,000 based on satellite images.
The population of king penguins was estimated to be between 2,168,640 and 2,456,640.
Major populations of penguins are found in Antarctica, Argentina, Australia, and New Zealand.
The majority of penguin species have declining populations according to the IUCN Red List.

sources.title: Penguin - Wikipedia
sources.snippet:
Major populations of penguins are found in Angola, Antarctica, Argentina, Australia, Chile, Namibia, New Zealand, and South Africa. Satellite images and photos released in 2018 show the population of 2 million in France's remote Ile aux Cochons has collapsed, with barely 200,000 remaining, according to a study published in Antarctic Science.

### Conservation status

The majority of living penguin species have declining populations. According to the IUCN Red List, their conservation statuses range from Least Concern through to Endangered. [...] | Species | IUCN Red List Status | Trend | Mature

sources.title: Penguin | Ultimate Pop Culture Wiki | Fandom
sources.snippet:
Several authors have suggested that penguins are a good example of Bergmann's Rule where larger bodied populations live at higher latitudes than smaller bodied populations. There is some disagreement about this, and several other authors have noted that there are fossil penguin species that contradict this hypothesis and that ocean currents and upwellings are likely to have had a greater effect on species diversity than latitude alone.

Major populations of penguins are found in Angola, Antarctica, Argentina, Australia, Chile, Namibia, New Zealand, and South Africa. Satellite images and photos

sources.title: Chinstrap penguin
sources.snippet:
## Conservation status

[edit]

In 2018, the IUCN estimated that the population of chinstrap penguins was around 8 million specimens. Although it is believed to be decreasing overall, its population is not severely fragmented; it is increasing or stable in many sites. The species is classified as least concern on the IUCN Red List as of 2016, due to its large range and population, following five previous assessments of the same status from 2004 to 2012 and three assessments as "unknown" from 1988 to 2000. sources.title: List of penguins - Wikipedia
sources.snippet:
There are currently 18 extant species of penguins recognised by the International Ornithologists' Union, distributed among six genera. Many species of fossil penguins are known from the Paleocene onwards; however, their exact number and taxonomy are unsettled due to ongoing discoveries.

## Conventions

[edit]

IUCN Red List categories

| Conservation status |
| EX | Extinct (0 species) |
| EW | Extinct in the wild (0 species) |
| CR | Critically endangered (1 species) |
| EN | Endangered (4 species) |
| VU | Vulnerable (4 species) |
| NT | Near threatened (2 species) |
| LC | Least concern (7

result.summary: As of the end of 2018, various penguin species populations were assessed, with chinstrap penguins estimated at 8 million, emperor penguins at 513,000, and king penguins between 2.1 and 2.5 million. Major populations are located in several southern hemisphere countries, and many species are experiencing population declines.

tasks.description: Find the Nature.com article titled 'global population assessment of the Chinstrap penguin' from 2020.

result.query: Find the Nature.com article titled 'global population assessment of the Chinstrap penguin' from 2020.

facts.fact: The article 'A global population assessment of the Chinstrap penguin' was published in 2020.
The authors of the article include Noah Strycker and Michael Wethington.
The assessment reports approximately 3.42 million breeding pairs of Chinstrap penguins.
The study was conducted using satellite imagery, drone imagery, and ground counts.

### A global population assessment of the Chinstrap penguin (Pygoscelis antarctica).

Noah Strycker, Michael Wethington, Alex Borowicz, Steve Forrest, Chandi Witharana, Tom Hart, Heather J Lynch

Author Information [...] Using satellite imagery, drone imagery, and ground counts, we have assembled the first comprehensive global population assessment of Chinstrap penguins (Pygoscelis antarctica) at 3.42 (95th-percentile CI: [2.98, 4.00]) million breeding pairs across 375 extant colonies.
